comment.author: 80878055@N00
comment._content: The family depicted is in fact Terris not Ferris and their residence Knappagh House is in the background. It is situated in the townland of that name about 3 miles west of Armagh city off the Battleford road. Here is the entry for the family in the 1911 census... www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Armagh/Glenaul/...

comment.author: 54403180@N04
comment._content: Thank you for this information, NIreland eye. I have corrected our title and description accordingly.
comment.authorname: Public Record Office of Northern Ireland

comment.author: 27618111@N03
comment._content:
I confirm, the man on the chair , at  right  ,is my grand father Jean Joseph Terris.
Olivier Terris France

comment.author: 80461056@N07
comment._content:
I can confirm that Knappagh house is in fact 5 miles west of Armagh city. I live in this house and the chair that Jean Joseph Terris is sitting on is still in the property and functioning :). This house has been in my family for over 120 years and has not changed much on the outside, the window panes are mostly the original glass. The woman sitting on the chair on the left is my great great grandmother Augustine Terris.

Hello Olivier. My mum Siobhan Terris met your grandfather Jean Joseph when she was 14.

Aisling Murray

comment.author: 80461056@N07
comment._content:
The gentleman sitting on the chair o the right is not Jean Joseph Terris, it is in fact Major Patrick Terris of Knappagh House.

Mairead Terris

comment.author: 93413451@N08
comment._content:
I am fascinated by this picture and its comments which my sister Oilbhe Tobin (formerly of Armagh) sent to me via Flickr. I had asked whether any of my siblings remembered the Terris family as our mother Peg Tobin used to mention them fondly, and I had read about their friendship with the painter John Luke whose work is in a special exhibition at the Ulster museum in Belfast at the moment. 

Gráinne Tobin
